Award.AwardTitle: Community Computational Platforms for Developing Three-Dimensional Models of Earth Structure, Phase II
Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal investigators of this proposal are a collaboration of seismologists, computer scientists, and structural geologists who are developing computational platforms that can combine seismological and geological information into three dimensional (3D) representations of Earth structure. They derive the seismological information from earthquakes, controlled-source experiments, and observations of the ambient seismic field generated by ocean waves and other near-surface disturbances. They derive the geological information from an even wider variety of sources: field mapping, electromagnetic remote sensing, geotechnical measurements, drilling and well-logging, fault trenching, and laboratory measurements of material properties.

The systematic integration of such diverse datasets into unified structural representations (USRs) is a key problem of geoinformatics. The goal of this project is to develop for community use the complex cyberinfrastructure needed to manage the ?USR lifecycle?, including the effective application of high performance computing (HPC) to invert joint datasets in the iterative improvement of USRs. The lifecycle is initiated by the integration of several components into a starting model; the starting model is refined by full-3D tomographic inversion of seismic waveform data; the refined model is validated for its proposed applications and then disseminated to user communities. This new model becomes the main component of the starting model for the next lifecycle.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A key problem of geoinformatics is the systematic integration of seismological and geological information into three-dimensional (3D) “unified structural representations” (USRs) that can be used in earthquake ground-motion forecasting, structural studies of Earth’s deep interior, and other geophysical applications. Our goal was to develop the cyberinfrastructure needed to manage a “USR lifecycle” that can progressively and efficiently refine 3D Earth models. The lifecycle is initiated by the integration of several components into a starting model; the starting model is refined by full-3D tomographic inversion of seismic waveform data; the refined model is validated for its proposed applications and then disseminated to user communities. This new model then becomes the main component of the starting model for the next lifecycle.

 

We have developed new high-performance computing (HPC) capabilities for refining USRs by full-3D tomography. Full-3D tomography accounts for the physics of wave excitation and propagation by numerically solving the inhomogeneous equations of motion for a heterogeneous, anelastic solid. The starting model is 3D, and the sensitivity (Fréchet) kernels are calculated using the full physics of 3D wave propagation. Full-3D tomography can employ any functional of the seismogram as observable, including frequency-dependent phase and group delays of earthquake waveforms and two-station correlagrams of the ambient seismic field. Full-3D tomography accounts for the nonlinearity of the structural inverse problem through iterated cycles of forward simulation, data measurement, kernel calculation, and inversion.

 

Our global focus has been on 3-D mantle structure needed to understand geodynamics. Our regional focus has been on California crustal structure needed for physics-based seismic hazard analysis. A major outcome has been the application of F3DT to iteratively improve the Southern California Earthquake Center (SCEC) Community Velocity Model to obtain CVM-S4.26. CVM-S4.26 shows strong crustal heterogeneities throughout Southern California. At shallow depths, the model provides much improved resolution of sedimentary basins. At middle to lower crustal depths, CVM-S4.26 provides new insights into regional tectonics and geologic evolution. Earthquake simulations using this model provide more accurate estimates of seismic hazards in Southern California.

 

We have developed three high-performance computational systems: a platform for synthesizing, comparing, and delivering Earth models and two platforms for full-3D tomography, based on the community codes for anelastic wave propagation. These codes have been optimized on supercomputers and used to derive new global and regional models. To facilitate access by the community to these models, the SCEC group has developed the Unified Community Velocity Model (UCVM) software framework, an open-source collection of tools that enables users to access one or more seismic-velocity models, while providing a standard query interface. This platform allows users to synthesize information from multiple sources in variable formats, including computer applications that allow for interactive querying of material properties.

 

The Harvard group has developed capabilities and tools to implement complex structural models in computational meshes and grids that can be used for full-3D tomography, earthquake hazard forecasting, and other applications. New methods to integrate a variety of models in a self-consistent manner have been implemented using novel metadata structures that relate information that can be used as constraints in the inversions and other applications.

 

The Princeton group developed a global inversion workflow consisting of four major stages: 1) forward simulations, 2) pre-processing and construction of adjoint sources, 3) gradient calculation, and 4) post-processing and model update. We addressed bottlenecks in the workflow, which mainly come from heavy I/O traffic during the simulation and processing stages. We defined an Adaptive Seismic Data Format (ASDF) and implemented it into our Python-based pre-processing tools and have implemented the use of ADIOS, developed by Oak Ridge National Laboratories, for computational databases.

 

Intellectual Merit. The intellectual merit derives from (a) the generality of the structural models, which are capable of representing a broad spectrum of heterogeneity controlled by a variety of geological processes, from the global scale of mantle dynamics to the small-scale, near-surface structure of sedimentary basins; (b) the power of our data assimilation approach, which employs full-3D tomography; and (c) the creation of a scientific workflow for progressive model refinement, which accelerates model development through the efficient use of high-performance computing.

 

Broader Impacts. The broader impacts derive from its potential to provide new information to a wide range of user communities, from basic researchers who are investigating the fundamental problems of lithospheric tectonics and mantle dynamics, to applied scientists and engineers who are trying to improve hazard analysis. Tomographic models with lateral dimensions of hundreds of kilometers, such as CVM-S4.26, are now being used to simulate earthquakes, predict strong ground motions, and provide an improved physical basis for seismic hazard analysis. Global tomographic models are being used to image the convective structure of the entire mantle and map its relationship to crustal tectonics and the geodynamo. Global and regional models are also improving the imaging of seismic sources, including earthquakes and nuclear explosions.
